div3.head: The great battle in the Valley.
div3.p:
Disconnected as our information is from the Valley, we have yet sufficient intelligence to satisfy us that our little army has covered itself with glory and won an imperishable renown.
History records not a more determined fight than that which has crowned the of Barton's Mills, in Frederick county, with an undying lustre.
The blood of the brave sons of Virginia was there poured out profusely, and the Yankee invaders have received a blow which robe their occupancy of the field of conflict of the meal of victory.--With our little army — scares 3,500 strong in the engagement--Gen. Jackson fought 18,000 of the foe for three hours, and only yielded the field when night closed in upon the struggle.
It was a desperate fight, a daring and gallant conflicts and although many a brave and gallant spirit has fallen upon our side whose lost we mourn, we rejoice in a combat which has tested and so fully proven the inextinguishable ardor of our Virginia military.
Better troops than those who fought in the battle of Sunday last were never drawn up in line of battle.
The testimony of Gen. Jackson is, that every man acted the hero.

The loss on both sides is very heavy; our own from 300 to 400; that of the enemy estimated at from 1200 to 1500.
Among the killed we have the names of Col. L. T. Moore, of Winchester, Thomas H. Townes, former delegate in the Legislature from Jefferson county, and Bushrod and George Washington, privates in the Botts Grays, from Jefferson in the wounded, we hear of Col. Echols, of the 20th regiment of Virginia volunteers, and Lieut. Richard Henry Lee, of the 2d regiment.
The latter was shot down while waving a flag and gallantly cheering his men, our pricely advance of his regiment.
This regiment is said to have sustained a loss of about one hundred.
Gen. Jackson had fallen back as far as Woodstock, point he was stationed on Tuesday night.

The gallant Ash by was picketing about five miles below the town, and fighting was going on between the pickets of the two armies.
The enemy were at Strasburg with a heavy
The following dispatch was received by Gov. Letcher last evening.

div4.p:
--Gen. Jackson's army is between Mount Jackson and Woodstock, in good condition.
Col. Echols was wounded in the arm near the shoulder.
Captains Robertson and Hollaway are wounded and taken prisoners.
Lieut. Junkin, instead of Major Jackson, is missing, 150 wounded arrived here this evening.
The Yankees fired on our flag of truce, and refused to permit us to bury the dead.
The enemy's loss is very heavy.
They were repulsed and driven from the field twice."
We append two dispatches which were received by gentlemen in this city yesterday afternoon.
--No one killed in Rockbridge artillery--four wounded. So soon at last of casualties gets here this evening, I will send it to you."

--5 o'clock P. M. Capt. Clarke has left Ashby safe.
Colonel Echols wounded. Our loss is 350--the enemy's much larger."

From a gentleman who came down on the train last evening, we learn that the withdrawal from the field was effected in the most admirable order, and that the finest spirit prevailed among the troops on Tuesday.
They were anxious for another conflict with the invading horde.
Gen. Shields, the Federal commander, is reported to be seriously wounded.

After the fight was ended, and our army had withdrawn from the field, the 5th Virginia regiment, which had been held as a reserve during the engagement, was sent forward with a flag of truce to bury the dead, when the dastardly enemy fired upon it, selling and wounding several.
Another evidence of the uncivilized warfare that is being waged upon us.

div3.head: A Sensible order.
div3.p:
The order we publish below will commend itself to every reflecting person.
It is well known that it is necessary to have the utmost system in the management of railroads, to promote the safety of persons and the maximum efficiency of the machinery.
To the Superintendent, who is best acquainted with the movement of the trains, the condition of the rolling stock and road, the grades, length of turnouts, and capacity of the several water stations, and to him alone, the subordinate officers look for orders; and when such orders are interfered with or countermanded by military officers, we are sure the interests of the Confederacy must suffer.
Where the transportation is so great as it has been during the war, it is impossible to effect it without the best system, and any interference, however good the intentions, may, and probably will, prevent such system from being carried out. Whenever, as in this order, the whole responsibility rests on the Superintendent, we may confidently say, all that can be done towards expediting Government demands, with the facilities at hand, will be. This order leaves the military men to do the fighting, and the Superintendents alone to do the running, in which capacity we are sure they will each do their part well.
Like all other orders emanating from its source, it is excellent, and will no doubt give universal satisfaction to the railroad officers throughout the Confederacy.

div4.p: General Orders, No. 1.

To avoid the danger, if not the certainty, of frequent collisions, and the consequent destruction of life and property, as well as obstruction to all transportation, it is absolutely necessary that the movements of railroad trains should be under one undecided control.
These considerations make it imperative that all trains should be regulated in their movements and speed only by their conductors and engineers, in accordance with the regulations and time-tables of the company.
All the operations of a road should be controlled by its Superintendent, or other authorized officer, and all orders for transportation of every kind, and the movement of every train, will be directed through him, when the exigencies of the service demand a variation from the regular schedule.
Disregard of this rule will inevitably be attended with disastrous consequences.
div4.closer:
By order of Gen. R. E. Lee.
W. H. Taylor, Asst. Adj. Gen.

div3.head: Supplemental report.
div3.p: We have before us the Supplemental Report of the Secretary of War with reference to the exchange of prisoners, and accompanied by the correspondence between Gen. Howell Cobb on the part of the Confederate States, and Gen. John E. Wool for the Government of the United States.

The first proposition for an exchange of prisoners was contained in a letter from Gen. Wool to Gen. Huger, under date of 18th of February, 1862, which proposition was agreed to by on Government, and the basis of a cartel submitted, which was accepted substantially by the representative of the United States.
Upon conferring with his Government however, his instructions were so changed that the end in view was defeated and the negotiations rather unceremoniously terminated.

The Secretary of War concludes his report with a recommendation that such of our own citizens as are now subject to parole be discharged.
We give the concluding paragraph of this recommendation:

q.p:
"I make no comment on these proceedings, further than to remark that it seems scarcely possible that there should be any further exchange of prisoners during the war. We can parole no prisoners with any expeotation of reciprocity, and can have no reliance on any promises that may be made.
I submit, however, that it is but bare justice to ourselves to declare discharged such of our own citizens as are now subject to parole, and so to inform the enemy, and thereafter to entertain no propositions on the subject of the exchange of prisoners except on delivery of held by the company and proposed her exchange.

div3.head:
Latest from Island no.10.
the fight still going on.
&c. &c. &c.
div3.p:
--A special dispatch to the Advertiser and Register, from Memphis, says that the bombardment of Island No.10 continues desperately, day and night.
The warm attack is directed at Rucker's battery.
The Confederates work knee deep in water, displaying great valor.
The loss on our side is slight.
Two of the enemy's gunboats are certainly sunk.

The enemy are moving down the west side of the river, through swamps and backwater, on dug outs.
They have four saw-mills at work making lumber to build boats.
The island is amply provisioned for the siege, and the Confederates are in good spirits.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch]
div4.p:
--Information was received from Island No.10 last night.
The cannonading on Sunday last was very heavy.
Two of the Yankee gunboats have been destroyed.
One was sunk below Hickman; the other went down in sight of the island.
Our troops on the island are in excellent spirits.
They declare that they can hold their position against the world.

The enemy's land forces at New Madrid are estimated at 40,000. Sixty of them came down in small boats, through the swamp, to Gayoso, and captured seven citizens, formerly attached to Gen. Thompson's army.

Yesterday the Confederate scouts at Corinth captured one hundred artillery horses belonging to the Yankees.
We were compelled to leave the guns, as the enemy were close at hand, and only the horses could be safely gotten away.
--Northern papers give up some intelligence from Island No.10.

A special dispatch to the New York Tribune, dated March 24th, says that at 9 o'clock on Sunday night the firing from Island No.10 was nearly stopped.
All day Sunday the firing was conducted slowly, and at night only at intervals of about half an hour.
Our (Federal) fire was mostly concentrated upon the upper battery, which is now falling to piece.

The battery has not replied for two days.--Only one gun can be seen in position, and that is a "quaker," (wooden.) The batteries on the main shore are also mysteriously silent.
The rebel encampments are growing smaller and smaller every day. Transports still continue flying about, apparently carrying away troops.
The river is still rising — everything is overflowed.
The rebels are fairly drowned out. They have been attempting the erection of new batteries, but the well-directed fire of our mortars prevented them from prosecuting their work.

A special dispatch to the Times. from Cairo, says the officers of the steamer Lake Erie, which left Island No.10 at 11 o'clock last night, saw the light of a large fire near the Kentucky shore, which kept increasing as they got up the river.
It was supposed to come from one of the rebel steamers or transports, set on fire by the bursting of shells.

Another dispatch to the Tribune, of Saturday night, says the gunboat Mound City fired twenty shot at the middle batteries with considerable effect.
Our officers, with the aid of a glass, counted five rebels killed by one shot.
On Sunday the effect of the mortars could not be ascertained, owing to the heavy weather.

A dispatch to the Secretary of War from Gen. Halleck, dated St. Louis, March 24th, says a detachment of the 1st cavally had set out from Jefferson City, under Gen. Totten, against a guerrilla party, and, skirmishing with the enemy, killed 2 and wounded 1, and captured 75 prisoners, over 20 horses and 48 kegs of powder, and a quantity of arms.
Our loss was 400.
Postmaster-General Blair has issued instructions to publishers not to publish anything that will gave information to the rebels, under penalty of exclusion from the mails.
By the arrival of the Hansa, from Europe, we have dates to the 12 inst.

In the House of Lords, Lord Campbell called attention to the inefficiency of the American blockade of Confederate ports, and moved for the publication of correspondence on the subject.
Lord Russell replied in proof against the charges advanced by Lord Campbell of inefficiency in the blockade, and recounted the efforts made by the North to render it effective.
He considered that the want of cotton in the English market was the best test that the blockade was not an empty one.

He, however, added, that a renewal of the old feeling between the North and the South was impossible, and hoped that the North would consent to a peaceful separation of the Southern States.
He trusted that within three months the war would close, believing that emancipation might possibly be effected by gradual and peaceful means.
He said that no formal communication had been made by the French Government in relation to the inefficiency of the blockade.

The Anile Childs, a screw steamer, arrived at Queenstown, from Wilmington, N. C., recently.
The ship Maria had arrived at Liverpool from Bombay, and on the voyage fell in with the brig Espero, from London, bound to New York, with a crew in a starving condition.
£200,000 sterling of Australian gold had arrived at England.

--American securities were firm.
The Asia arrived to-day.
Liverpool markets dull-- Cotton closed dull; sales Monday and Tuesday 8,000 bales; 3,000 bales were bought by speculators, the balance by exporters.
Prices were unchanged.
Breadstuffs dull.

--Wendell Phillips, the notorious Abolitionist, attempted to lecture here, at the Opera House, to — night, but met with rather an unexpected demonstration.
He announced himself an abolitionist and a disunionist, whereupon he was egged and stoned.
He was rescued by some friends.

--A dispatch from Winchester, from the Surgeon-General of Shield's army, to the Surgeon General at Washington, says in relation to the battle of Sunday, that our (Federal) loss was from 75 to 100 killed and 250 wounded. He had seen 225 of the rebels dead.

--The rebels have been driven back to Strasburg with heavy loss.
One French officer came up to-day.--All quiet here.

div3.head: Yankee account from North Carolina--reported destruction of the Nashville.

div4.p: --We have the following from Fortress Monroe, dated 23d March:

"The steamer Chancellor, Livingston, arrived from Hatteras last night and brings intelligence that immediately after the occupation of Newbern, the expedition started to Beaufort, N. C. That place was found to have been evacuated before our (Federal) troops approached.
For Macon was blown up by the rebels, and the rebel steamer Nashville was burnt the day Gen. Burnside occupied Newbern.
It has been ascertained that 16,000 rebel troops are now on the road from Goldsboro', to reinforce the rebels of Newbern.
The steamer Swaps sailed Fortress Monroe for Hatteras on the 29th March with mails and passengers."

div4.p: --The reported destruction of Fort Macon and the steamer Nashville is confirmed.

Col. Segar, representative elect from Accomac District, Va., arrived here this morning, and confirms the intelligence of the destruction of the privateer?

div3.head: The Yankees in Florida.
div3.p:
--The Savannah Republican, of this morning, says that the Yankees are in full possession of St. John's river, Florida.
About 2,500 Federals are at Jacksonville, Fla. They have torn up the railroad track, and are using the iron in the defence of the city.

Another special dispatch to the same paper, from Baldwin, Fla, says that a small detachment of Confederates stole upon the Yankee guard at Jacksonville, killing four and capturing three. Lieut. Strange, of the Confederate party, was wounded, and, it is feared, mortally.

div3.head: Movement of the enemy in Tennessee.
div3.p:
--A special dispatch to the New Orleans Picayune, from Memphis, says that the enemy is moving cautiously towards Decatur.
One column is moving Southward from Columbia; another moving across Tennessee, from the direction of Corinth.
It is believed that their purpose is to unite their two or more columns at some point on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, near Decatur.

Richmond, March 24, 1862.
div3.p:
General Orders, No. 16.--All leaves of absence and furloughs, from whatever source obtained, are revoked; and officers and men absent from duty, except on surgeon's certificate of disability, will return at once to their respective commands.
It is with extreme reluctance that the Department adopts a measure which deprives our patriotic soldiers of the relaxation they have so well earned; but the enemy presses on every side, and the necessities of the service demand new illustrations of that noble self-denial which has been so many times evinced since the commencement of our struggle for independence.
The furloughs of all who have engaged for the war, which are thus curtailed, will be extended hereafter, when circumstances permit.
But, judging from the past, no fears are entertained of an unwilling response to this call.
Those who have so many times proved their devotion to their country, cannot be indifferent or backward in this hour of her greatest need.
div3.closer:
By order of the President.
S. Coopers,

div3.p:
I will be in Manchester until Monday, 31st inst., for the purpose of obtaining Recruits for his company, stationed at present at Sewell's Point Battery, Norfolk harbor.
All desirous of joining a good company, which has seen service, can communicate with me at my store in Manchester.
Recruits will be entitled to the usual bounty of $50 and pay for clothing.

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a battalion or regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to undertake to do so until this time and I sow propose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry, if it can be done without assenting myself too much from my present command.
Persons desting to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place; or what is still better, sport in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of try and one of artillery attached to my command.

Call for the present at Messrs. Yarbrough's south side of Main street, three a above 7th or at my company quarters.
New Fair Grounds.

Heavy Artillery.
$50 bounty, and
Uniforms furnished.
div3.p:
The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, up stairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.

div3.p:
this well-known company having determined to remain in the service, is desirous of increasing the number of enlisted men to 125.
A Recruiting Office has been opened for that purpose at the store of Louis.
J. Bosaleux 30 Main street, and also at the store of Joseph Butler, town of Manchester.
All young men who are disposed to volunteer can learn the particulars of the condition and organization of the company from Lieut. Henry Fitzgerald, who can be found either place of rendezvous.
Recruits are entitled to pay, transportation, and subsistence, from the time and place of enrollment, and also to the bounty of fifty dollars.

I hope that this call may meet with a speedy response and that I may never be a witness to the drafting of young men from the districts in the neighborhood of Richmond.
All recruits are to be persons of good character, and men in whom I can place implicit co ence.

I Am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Infantry Company, and as no more new companies will be accepted until Virginia's quota has been furnished (this company will be counted as a part of it,) this is one of the few last chances to escape the draft; and who would be drafted?
Men accepted from all parts of the State or Confederacy.
Twelve months men can re-enlist with me. $50 bounty paid as soon as inspected.
Recruiting office at the office of the Insurance Company of the State of Virginia, under the American Hotel, Richmond, Va. Address me,

The usual bounty of $50 will be paid when the roll is signed and the volunteer sworn in.
Call at P. H. Starke's, Main, between 14th and 15th streets, for the present.

div3.head: Recruits wanted for an Infirmary Company.
div3.p:
--Having obtained from the Secretary of War authority to organize an Infirmary Company, to go into the active service of the Confederate States for the war, I respectfully call upon all persons subject to militia duty to enlist in this new branch of the service.
This company's duties will be to attend the wounded soldiers on a field of battle, and to prevent them from bleeding to death.
The company will be stationed a short distance in the rear of the line of battle, to immediately dress the wounds of each soldier wounded and remove him from the field to some proper hospital.
Each man enlisting will receive the bounty of $50. Uniforms and equipments also furnished.
Having nearly my complement of men, I should like to receive about 30 more good recruits.
Apply soon at my recruiting office, Broad street, between 6th and 7th streets.

div4.p: --We are authorized to raise a regiment of infantry to be stationed near Portsmouth; and we have the assurance of the Secretary of War that the regiment will be pt near Portsmouth as long as any troops are requited for its defence.
We are happy to state that we have every prospect of the early completion of the regiment.
We have established, for the present our rendezvous at the winter quarter lately occupied by the Third Georgia regiment, situated near Portsmouth.

Volunteers and recruits will be received at our rendezvous by companies squads, or singly and they will be forth with mustered into service, and be to pay, subsistence, &c., from the time of their being mustered in. Persons raising companies for our regiment may advantageously make our rendezvous the headquarters for their recruits.

Companies now in service can re-enlist for our regiment by having it so designated by the mustering officer on their muster rolls when they re-enlist; and they will be transferred at the expiration of the present term of their enlistment from their present regiment to ours.

Individuals in any company, now in service, can re-enlist for our regiment by having it designated on their muster rolls at the time of their re-enlistment and they will be transferred from their present companies and regiments in our regiment on the expiration or their present term of enlistment.
Re-enlisted men re-enlisting for our regiment will be entitled to join together and organize themselves into companies, and to elect their company officers.
All persons wishing to re-enlist for our regiment must re-enlist under he Confederate law.
Persons volunteering or re-enlisting to our regiment will be entitled to the ough provide , for by law.
Organized companies, or re-enlisted nomourn, will be mustered in at any time, by application to the proper officer, or to Lieut J F to their being mustered in.

Lieut. Col, Crocker will superintend the rendezvous at the winter quarters lately occupied by the Third Georgia regiment, and he will be found there or at the Mason Hotel.
Portsmouth at any time.
He will give any information required, and will receive recruits and make immediate provision for them.
All communications addressed to Colonel D. J. Godwin, Suffolk, Va., 14th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, or to Lieut Col. J. F. Crocker, Portsmouth, will be promptly attended to.

div4.p:
I have consented, at the request of the Legislature of Virginia, to accept no more additional companies, battalions, or regiments of volunteers in Virginia, until after the quota of the State has been furnished for the war; but this does not in any manner interfere with authority previously granted to raise companies battalions or regiments within the State of Virginia.
Any companies, therefore which may have been, or may be, raised or organized under the authority granted Lieut Col. Godwin to raise a regiment for the war, will be accepted, and may be mustered into service in conformity with the terms of that authority.

Recruits--
Richmond sharp-shooters.
div3.p:
Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well-known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date of enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has sustained an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Rifles, and has seen as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange, Bank street, or to Corporal W. J. Wingfield.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Second Company of Richmond Howitzers has been reorganized, and Lieutenant David Watson elected Captain.
We are anxious to increase the number of our Company to 120.
An opportunity is thus offered to young men of good moral character to join an old organization, which has two rifles and two howitzers, and is thoroughly equipped for field service.

Apply to R. B. Pleasants or Henry S. Jone., No. 7, Wall street, under St. Charles Hotel; or Wm. N. Wellford, Jr., Brandy Station, Culpeper county, Virginia, r Geo. L. Christian, Charles City C. H., Virginia.

div3.head: Attention — Boggs's Battalion Flying Artillery.
div3.p:
The undersigned having authority to raise a Company, to form a part of this splendid corps, for which the most approved light rifled pieces are now being turned out, all those wishing to join a select company, and avoid the militia, will do well to enroll themselves at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.
The special attention of the militia is invited to the fact that we are authorized to give the most positive assurance that no man enlisting in this company remains liable either to the present cell of the Governor, or to any future draft upon the militia.
Who will wait to be a drafted militiaman?
Apply at the Recruiting Office of the Battalion, Bank street, near the corner of 12th Bounty down--fifty dollars.
We refer particularly to Major Boggs's card, calling on those who wish to enter his corps to report to the officers of this company.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, on the 8th of March, my man Austin.
He is about 50 years old, 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high in of a ginger cake color, has a full head of hair, and walks one leg being shorter than the other, caused by white swelling when he was young.
He has relations in the upper end of Powhatan or Cumberland, where I expect he has gone; or else he may be about Richmond.
Austin is a good shoes maker, and may perhaps pace himself off as a free negro.
I will give the above reward to any one who will bring him to me, or secure him in jail so I get him.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p: --I will pay we above reward for the apprehension of my negro, Bob. He is lurking about Baker and Jackson streets. He is of medium height, black, thin visage, and talks with a hern accent.

Fifty Dollars reward.
Will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me of my negro man Abram, if taken outside the city or county, and $25 if within.
He will doubtless try to go to Fredericksburg on the railroad, track.
He is 29 years old; black; heavy build; 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high had on light colored full cloth clothes; heavy brogans.
He was brought from King George county, Va, on Monday last.
div3.closer:
W. C. Lton,
Monument Hotel. mh 25--tw*

div3.head: Ranaway--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--Left without provocation, about the 1st January last, my boy Henry, about 26 years of age, a barber by trade, hired for the present year to Wermer & Co., opposite the American Hotel.
Henry is a spare, brown colored boy, about 5½ feet high, genteel address, wears a small beard, with full head of hair.
He may have hired himself to go with some officer or soldier.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me or Mr. Wermer, or any information of his whereabouts, so that I get him

div3.head: Runaway--$25 reward
div3.p:
--Dr. John, a Fellow man, to bright, with quite a full head of hair, inclined to be very bushy.
He want to the 2d Market with my on the 17th of March and left the cart in the street and has not since been seen of heard from.
I will give the above reward if taken in this State and $50. If taken in any other State John is quite intelligent and very polite.
He is about 28 to 30 years old, and has a small scar on one of his hands.
He was dressed with blue homespun pants and dark overcoat, and drab-colored felt hat, when he left.
He was hired by me of Wm. N. Yarbour, adm'r of Jesse Yarbour, dec'd, of Hanover.
I will pay the above reward and all expenses if delivered to me in Richmond or lodged in jail so that I get him again

div3.head: Ranaway--$200 reward
div3.p:
--From the residence of the subscriber, on the 30th Nov. Negro Boy Isaac, about 30 years old, 5½ feet high, ginger-bread complexion, of pleasant and polite manners, hair short and happy, and is left handed.
I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of said boy in the jail at Orange C. H.

This negro ran off in consequence of having committed a most brutal and unprovoked murder upon the person of my overseer, and it behooves the community at large to be on the look-out for this criminal.
He may be in the vicinity of Fredericksburg, where he has acquaintances.
